text: Hi, everyone. Welcome to Unconfirmed, the podcast that reveals how the market names in crypto are reacting to the week's top headlines and gets the inside scoop on what they see on the horizon. I'm your host, Laura Shin. Crypto.com, the crypto super app that lets you buy, earn, and stun crypto in one place. Download the crypto.com app today. Etoro is one of the largest trading platforms in the world. With over $1 trillion in trading volume on a platform per year, us. Customers can trade the most popular crypto assets with transparent fees. Create an account today@etoro.com that's eToro.com Crypto Law, aka Kelman Law, is a New York law firm run by some of the first lawyers to enter crypto in 2013 with expertise in litigation, dispute resolution, and antimoney laundering. Email them at info at kelman law. Today's guest is Elizabeth Stark, co founder and CEO of lightning Labs. Welcome, Elizabeth.
speaker: A

text: Hey, Laura. It's great to be here.
speaker: B

text: This week you announced a $10 million Series A funding round led by Craft Ventures. Congratulations.
speaker: A

text: Thank you. It's been quite a week.
speaker: B

text: Yes, I know, because you emailed me very late last night. I was like, she must have had a long day. So at the same time, you also announced the beta launch of Lightning Loop, which is your first paid product. Why don't we talk about that first? What is Lightning Loop?
speaker: A

text: Yeah, sure. So Lightning Loop is a product that we at Lightning Labs developed to make it more efficient to send and receive bitcoin on the Lightning network. And the nature of Lightning is such that you have amazing speed, amazing scalability, and very low fees. But there is a requirement of liquidity. And what that means is if you want to receive funds on Lightning, you need what we call inbound liquidity to do so. And then this is more obvious to the average individual. But if you want to send funds, you need funds on the side that you're going to send. So you need the ability to, say, have money in your account. And so what Lightning Loop does is it helps people reallocate their funds in the network. So, for example, if a lot of people have sent me funds on Lightning already and I no longer have that inbound capacity or liquidity, as we call it, I then can no longer keep receiving those funds. So Lightning Loop could actually help people by moving their funds from Lightning back to the bitcoin blockchain in a non custodial manner so they could keep receiving. And then similarly, if you want to send funds on Lightning, you can actually refill your channel. Think of it as refilling an account using Lightning Loop by swapping funds from the bitcoin blockchain onto Lightning. So an analogy I sometimes use, loop in, as we call it when you refill your channel, is kind of like refilling a prepaid debit card or an account. Loop out is a little bit harder because we don't usually have that concept. But if you had a cash register full of cash and you actually had to take the cash out, and then you can continue to receive money in that register, that's how that works. So we at Lightning Loop have built this product. We already had it in Alpha, had quite a lot of startups involved. Some great folks like Fold have been users of it, and it's helping their businesses. It's helping them more effectively send and receive funds on Lightning. And we've gotten a lot of good feedback so far. And we announced the beta with increased limits for people to be able to move their funds in and out of Lightning from the bitcoin blockchain.
speaker: B

text: And what have the limits been and what are they now?
speaker: A

text: So, Lightning network generally today has a limit of around $1,500 per channel. So channels are kind of like accounts on the network. People open multiple channels between two participants. On Loop, there's also a transaction limit, which is zero point 42 BTC. So it's about 300 and $350 depending upon the price of bitcoin at the day. Loop originally was capped previously at half that. So about 150 USD. Now it's up to around 300 and 350. And that will stay in place while the caps are present on the Lightning network more broadly. But there's something called Wombo, kind of like Jumbo with a W that is derived from SpongeBob. And Credit co founder Lalu I am not a SpongeBob. I just missed the whole SpongeBob thing. But he's really into it. And that is about larger channel sizes on Lightning. So today we still have these limits in place. We chose to do so for safety and security reasons, but with Wimbo, it will be opt in larger channel sizes. So the good news is somebody won't unintentionally open a massive channel and not realize what they're doing. But if they choose to do so, they'll be able to opt in and put more capital onto Lightning in these channels. So with Lumbo and the broader network will also increase loop capacities as well.
speaker: B

text: And so, as you know, the limits so far have been pretty small. But you did talk about some of the companies that were building on them. So what are the typical applications that companies are using Lightning for now?
speaker: A

text: Yeah, so we've seen a whole host of startups emerge, which has been really incredible. Less than two years ago at Lightning Labs, we released the beta version of our L D implementation of the Lightning network. There are numerous implementations. There's C lightning from blockstream, there's eclair from Async. So we built ours, we released this beta. And since then, we've seen a whole new crop of startups emerge that didn't even exist prior to this. And many of them are focused on Lightning first. So there are a few categories of these. One that I know our head of operations, Desiree Dickerson loves is the rise of the Lightning gaming startup. So quite a few video game companies have emerged. There's ZBD, Donner, lab, satoshi's games, where they're integrating lightning payments into their video games. So I think that's a really cool use case. We've seen lightning payment startups where you can buy things with lightning. So we have fold bit refill. OpenNode is helping people, is a payment processor. There's BTC pay, where merchants can integrate bitcoin and lightning and run their own software in order to do so. So there's the ability to then pay with lightning. There's lightning pizza, which is a cool project from fold, where you can order pizza with lightning. In some cases with fold, I believe you get SATS back as well. Then we have the earning with lightning companies. There's a great one called stack. I mean, look, who doesn't want more bitcoin? I want more bitcoin, right? So people think of lightning as people spending bitcoin, but there's actually huge potential for people earning bitcoin as well. So stack is a really great startup. Just saw the founder last night where people can complete these small tasks if, you know, Amazon mechanical Turk, and then they earn satoshis on lightning. Because think about it this way, if you wanted to pay people around the world in a variety of different countries to do small value tasks, and you wanted to do it in the fiat system, good luck. That's just not going to be possible. So stack is a great way to complete tasks, do this micro work, and earn with lightning. And then there are companies like tipin and a variety of products where you can actually tip people and again, earn. People can actually make money with lightning. And then we see the rise of the lightning financial startup, and there are quite a few of these as well. River financial, for example, and disclosure personally, in my personal capacity, I'm an advisor. They've integrated LND lightning, where you can deposit and withdraw, and you can buy bitcoin with dollars and withdraw directly on lightning, or you can deposit and then sell. For USD, we have Escher, which is building a lightning native API. We have Sparkswap, which is doing trading. We have Zap, which is doing OTC. You can transact between USD and lightning. So we have a whole host of those. And then we have the wallets. There's some great ones like breeze, moon. Zap is also working on a wallet. There's blue wallet, wallet of satoshi. So there's really been just this huge ecosystem that has emerged in less than two years. And this past fall, we co organized a lightning conference. We had 500 developers, enthusiasts, community members in Berlin. People came from all around the world, every continent, and it was incredible to see that in person and to really see it be tangible and to enter this world of lightning where everyone was buying. There was a lightning beer tap, a lightning cocktail bot. You could buy ice cream, hot chocolate, all sorts of interesting things with lightning. You could play video games with lightning. There was a lightning scooter, there was a Tesla coil where when you paid it, it actually sparked. Like, who knew that would be possible, right? Yesterday, I actually live on yahoo finance livestream, our head of operations, and I fed the chickens on you know what I love about this community is there are real businesses being built on top of it, but there are also these crazy use cases. You're like, wait, if I thought a few years ago that the tech we were building was going to help us feed chickens, who knew?
speaker: B

text: But hey, it I'm actually oh, man. Was it Chris Dixon? Or was it Fred Wilson? One of them said something. Know the technologies that will be big some days start off looking like games and like fun to people.
speaker: A

text: Yeah, I think they ended up so now it's like a yeah, yeah.
speaker: B

text: And a couple other things I just wanted to refer back to for people who don't know, which I suspect is just a small percentage of my listeners. But just in case, when Elizabeth talked about earning SATS back, that's satoshis. And a satoshi is the smallest unit of bitcoin, which is eight decimal places.
speaker: A

text: Exactly. Today, one satoshi is about nine thousandths of a cent. And it's interesting because in the lightning community, we've actually moved to the SATS denomination, and there's a whole meme around stacking SATS, and I like the earning SATS one, too. Maybe we need more alliteration there. But the community in the lightning world actually operates in satoshis, which I think is really interesting and different. And you're like, wow, I got 10,000 satoshis. And you're like, oh, wait, it's actually just $0.10.
speaker: B

text: Yeah. But I do think that there is something about thinking about money in new ways. It's like a new behavior and something new. I remember when you and I met in person and you showed me I forget the name of it, but the clock, or not the clock, sorry, exactly. So it's this little, I don't know what you call it. You can make a sign and it will flip these letters, but you basically pay with lightning and then you can tell it what sign you want to put up there. So, of course I said something like, you have to listen to unchained.
speaker: A

text: I saw that, that was cool.
speaker: B

text: But anyway, so for people who didn't know that and then the other thing I wanted to mention or ask you about actually, was you talked about how lightning loop is enabling payment processing, but obviously we've had payment processors in bitcoin before. How is lightning loop different from the previous bitcoin payment processors?
speaker: A

text: Totally, one quick correction, 1000 SATS is just did the math in my head. Okay. Yeah. So lightning loop is not an end user interface, so companies that are facilitating payment will use loop, if that makes sense. So fold a company that is enabling people to purchase with Lightning at major retailers order Lightning Pizza, I believe they operate via gift cards, where then you can get discounts and you also get SATS back. So Fold is going to be the user of our product. So it's more of the customers are the startups, and then the end users will interact with Fold. So although it's not a perfect analogy by any means, but Stripe is a company where if Fold was using credit cards, they would interact with Stripe and then Fold would work with Stripe and Fold would work with the end user. So Stripe is not a perfect analogy because we don't charge per transaction on the network. The network is an open protocol. Anyone could build on top of it. But we're building tools, and Loop is the first of several that will make it more efficient and easier. And by improving that efficiency, the goal is we work with these startups and we empower them to build their businesses. So does that make sense? So we're not building an end user product where BTC Pay is another great example of if you're a merchant and you want to integrate Bitcoin and Lightning, you can run BTC Pay. And we're not building that merchant front end, although merchants might actually be interested in loop via something like BTC Pay.
speaker: B

text: As and but one key piece also is that they don't actually take custody when they do it. So it enables the yes.
speaker: A

text: And loop itself is non custodial. And that's a really important point as a business at, you know, we don't want to hold other people's money. We think that the technology opens up this new world where never before have you been able to have financial products where you don't have custody. In the pre Bitcoin world, a bank had to have your funds, or if you were trading securities, a broker had to hold your securities. There was not this concept of noncustodial financial products, but these new technologies enable that. So we as a company are focused on that. I don't want to build a bank. I don't want to hold other people's money. I know there are a lot of regulatory questions around holding other people's money, so we are just building the technical infrastructure to make it possible for people to do things with their funds.
speaker: B

text: All right, so in a moment, we're going to discuss more about Lightning loop as well as Lightning Labs's Series A. But first, a quick word from the sponsors who make this show possible. Or just go to their website at WW crypto law. When you think crypto, think Kelman. Are you interested in getting into the cryptocurrency markets but don't know where to start building your portfolio? With Etoro, you get access to the world's most popular cryptocurrencies with transparent trading fees, all in one easy to use app. Copy the smart money with Etoro. Join. Now@etoro.com that's eToro.com. Back to my conversation with Elizabeth Stark of Lightning labs. So, as you know, your Lightning Labs will not be charging per transaction, but how will Lightning Labs make money from loop?
speaker: A

text: So loop is already in production, and people are already using it, and we're already taking fees on this. So there's a percentage fee, which can vary in terms of the amount that you transact in loop. So, for example, you don't always need loop when you're transacting. But let's say you're a company, and then you've gotten a lot of inbound payments, and now you need additional liquidity or ability to receive inbound payments, then you would do a loop, as we call it, and that would give you the liquidity and capacity to receive funds. So we take a percentage on that transaction, if that makes sense. So, broadly speaking, there's a volume that will occur on the loop product, and then we take a small fee on that.
speaker: B

text: And going back to your $10 million raise, which we sort of glossed over at the beginning, what do you plan to do with that money?
speaker: A

text: Yeah, totally. First of all, I just want to say you don't often hear this from founders, or maybe they say it publicly, but they don't actually mean it. But our investors have been amazing, and I'm really grateful to be working with them. And they're all fans of Lightning. Just yesterday, we were with our new board member who was wearing his Holo knot T shirt, right? You know, it's like, how many VCs wear Hodlonaut T shirts and exactly. Yeah. Brian Murray. Of course. So we brought together an amazing group of people that really care deeply about this ecosystem, and a lot of them are also funding the onward startups that are building on Lightning. But as a company, I don't see this fundraise in and of itself as an accomplishment. To me, it's a means to an end. And the end is really building out the technology, building the developer ecosystem, building the startups. And our focus as a company as well, I want to build for real users, I want to enable real use cases, I want to solve real problems. And I do think at a higher level, some part of the community broadly in cryptocurrency has lost touch with that and I'm trying to really bring this to solving real problems with real users and making these things easier to use. So for the funding, the main goal is really to continue building out the technology, to build out the business. Most of the money will likely go to hiring. We as a startup are not spending huge amounts of money. We have ICOs out there with hundreds of millions of dollars and we've shipped in many cases, I think, way more than that on a couple of million. So the goal is really to build out the technology, hire some great people. I don't believe in hiring 100 people at once. Hire high impact individuals that can really make a difference. I was once actually chatting with somebody who was a big name in the financial world and explaining Lightning and Bitcoin today is $170,000,000,000 economy and they said to me, oh, how many people do you have? 500? And I said, at that time we're eleven. So really the impact and the scale at which we can build things I think is different from what you see in a lot of the traditional financial world because individual developers and team members can have a huge impact. Yeah, and by the way, even the Lightning Protocol itself today, amongst the implementations that are out there for mainnet, I think less than ten full time protocol developers, which is wild. Of course we at Lightning Labs are working on some other products, as you know. But in terms of the core protocol, there really aren't very many people out there.
speaker: B

text: Yeah, well, I mean, this is something I think about a lot, because I do feel like the technology can replace a lot of the people at these huge financial services firms, which yeah.
speaker: A

text: And another note on the fundraise. So we have both great people from the tech side of things, and then we brought in a lot of the people from the financial world that are getting really interested and excited about Lightning. So we had a lot of that New York financial representation because they understand the potential of Bitcoin to be this Internet money and both as a global store of value, but a global transaction platform and a global trading platform. And we also had people with the broader perspective internationally. So the goal was to bring together people from a variety of different areas of expertise.
speaker: B

text: Yeah, well, I was going to ask you about this because some of your investors were really traditional financial know there was Howard Morgan of Renaissance Technologies, Arca Group, and first round capital. There was John Feffer, formerly of private equity firm KKR. So I was curious to know, what is it like making a pitch to an investor from traditional finance? Do they tend to have different questions, or do they tend to have a different perspective on the potential in the technology? Or do you find that they more and more just have a typical kind of crypto mindset?
speaker: A

text: Yeah, we also have Ross Stevens, the CEO of Stone Ridge, which is, I believe, a 16 billion asset manager, david B. Heller, who was global co head of securities at Goldman Sachs. These people believe in bitcoin. Right. So in my experience, if somebody is super skeptical, converting them can take a while. But when people understand the potential here and John Feffer, by the way, has done amazing work in funding the bitcoin developer ecosystem and has written great research around, you know, we're not converting people that know bitcoin was a joke. Right. We're working with people that see this potential. But Howard Morgan has a great computer science background. I had some great technical discussions where I was explaining lightning routing and the variety of the technologies we're building, and he just got it because he was like, oh, I worked on similar things in the 80s, which I thought was so interesting and cool. So from our standpoint, these are people that understand that there's a massive future for bitcoin and they see the potential of lightning. And I think we're seeing more and more of that in the traditional financial world. And I love the forward thinking visions that are coming along with it.
speaker: B

text: And, I mean, earlier you talked about how you do plan to hire and stuff with your new round of investment, but I was also wondering what are some of the problem areas that you feel need to be solved with this technology that you'd like to work on?
speaker: A

text: Definitely. So one of the big areas for bitcoin more broadly, and that's also present in Lightning is bitcoin is not terribly easy to use today. Right. You have this complicated address, either BC one or starting with a three or starting with a one. People don't typically think it's easy to use. Now, Lightning has been on main net with a variety of betas for less than two years, right? 22 months or so. So we know that it's not there yet. But to me, getting toward a world in which Lightning is really usable, in some cases, users might not even know they're using it. I think that's quite a possibility moving forward, say, fast forward five years from now. I think it's key. And ideally, users are just transacting either via QR codes or there can be NFC type technologies in apps where it's seamless and it's super simple. Things even like backups for non custodial wallets, can get challenging. So one of the big challenges I see and something I'm really passionate about is how can we design this technology so that the end users can interact with it more effectively. And we're seeing a lot of great wallets out there that have been working on this as well and trying to make lightning more usable. And so for Lightning Labs, we do these things called Roundtables. We had one for companies integrating LND and then one for the walls building upon LND, and we want to know what their needs are in terms of the infrastructure and the protocol. So I see this new crop of wallets that has emerged as a way to make this technology more usable and bring it to a wider variety of people. And for example, just a week and a half ago, video conference into Venezuela I've never been there, would love to go one day to a meetup there, and they were discussing Lightning, and it was kind of a surprise appearance, and it was really cool. And they actually created their own lightning torch internally at the meetup, and people were sending the funds around. So, to me, if we can get to a point where this technology is more usable and more accessible, I believe it'll happen. But it just takes time. And we need to progress the infrastructure. We need to build better usable interfaces. I think Jack Mueller's at Zap has done an incredible job with that. There are quite a few wallets out there where people are really thinking about making the technology more.
speaker: B

text: Yeah, I watched his video last week of this new Strike app, and I was like, oh, it's similar to what you were saying, where you could use the technology and not know it.
speaker: A

text: Exactly.
speaker: B

text: It was very seamless. Yeah.
speaker: A

text: And an analogy I like to use is, well, email. Right? So there's an underlying protocol called SMTP that powers the email that people are using. But people don't know they're using SMTP. They just know they're sending and receiving messages. So, similarly, I can see a day in the future where people are sending and receiving with lightning and they don't even fully realize that lightning is underlying it, but it's powering a lot of what they're doing on the Internet in terms of sending and receiving money. There have also been some applications that have emerged that are lightning chat applications where people are actually sending messages on the network. And that has become a little bit controversial. It's funny how they're like developer controversial things in the community because some people think it's spam. But right now, the way that it's constructed in the protocol, you don't have to guarantee a payment, but that's actually going to change. But Yoast Jaeger on the Lightning Labs team has, in his personal capacity, built an app called Whatsat. That is a way to send and receive on the command line. And then people have been building UIs. The company Stack has built Sphinx, which is a lightning chat app. So people are sending tiny fractions of a penny in order to send and receive messages. So the idea that lightning in and of itself can be a broader data layer is emerging where there are a variety of different applications where you can send small value payments along with them. So that's been something interesting to see evolve as well.
speaker: B

text: Oh, interesting? I haven't heard of that.
speaker: A

text: It's new. There's always new progress in this community.

text: Yeah, that's what I like to keep my eye on, is all sort of the fun little things going on. All right, well, congratulations again on your raise, and thank you so much for coming on Unconfirmed.
